results.title: Secular soul. Part 2. Ceremonies [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Compass (Television program)”.
Presented by Geraldine Doogue, this three part series looks at the changing patterns of belief in Australia. Episode two examines the civil celebrant movement and the increase in rituals involving civil celebrants as opposed to traditional religious leaders. Doogue speaks to civil celebrant Dally Messenger, one of Australia’s longest practising civil celebrants, Diane Storey who specializes in funerals, John Hill, an ex Roman Catholic priest who missed the rituals of the church and became a civil celebrant, Gael Brigden, a celebrant on a television program, and Paul Charvet-Jackson who specialises in same sex commitment ceremonies. The celebrants share their thoughts on what inspires them, how they devise the rituals, the preparation that takes place, and the future of their profession. Features footage of weddings, a naming day and interviews with people who have enlisted the services of the celebrants. Part of the television show, “Compass”.

group_siblings.title: Secular soul. Part 1. Spiritual market place [Widescreen]

results.title: Secular soul. Part 1. Spiritual market place [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Compass (Television program)”.
Presented by Geraldine Doogue, this three part series looks at the changing patterns of belief in Australia. Episode one examines the decline in attendance at traditional churches and the incidence of “spiritual shopping” whereby people are creating their own personal style of religion. In looking at the decline in church attendance since the 1960s and the melding of the experiential and the emotional, Doogue speaks to university lecturers Carole Cusack and David Tacey, Uniting Church Minister and director of the Christian Research Association Philip Hughes, and Anglican priest and sociologist Gary Bouma. The program also looks at the growth in Pentecostal churches, spending time at the Mount Annan Christian Life Centre, speaking to Andrew and Adrian Gray about their work. Youths also describe their experiences during an empowering conference. Features vox pops at Sydney nightclub and Acland Street, St Kilda. Part of the television show, “Compass”.

results.title: Tintin et les Oranges Bleues
results.brief_description:
Professor Zalamea, a Spanish scientist, sends to Prof. Tournesol a blue orange with mysterious properties. But the orange is stolen soon after. Tintin, Captain Haddock and Snowy set off in hot pursuit

Credits: Director, Philippe Condroyer ; writer, Andre Barret ; photography, Jean Badal ; music, Antoine Duhamel.
Cast: Jean-Pierre Talbot, Jean Bouise, Jenny Orleans, Felix Fernandez, Max Elloy.

results.title: Sea animals
results.creator_credit: Tom Gordon, Video School and Dorling Kindersley Vision
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “See how they grow”.
Another interesting episode in this instructional series on animals designed for young children. This program focuses on four sea creatures from infancy to adulthood. The animals featured are the Ray, a cousin of the shark; the Pipe-Fish, a fascinating eel-like fish; the Cuttlefish whose skeleton is a familiar sight on the beach and the Hermit Crab which hides in a shell to preserve its privacy.

results.title: See how they grow
results.creator_credit: Tom Gordon, Dorling Kindersley Vision and Video School
results.brief_description: A delightful and entertaining natural history series for young children with superb live action photography charting the growth of animals. We watch the animals growing and share their adventures as they learn about their new world.

results.title: Secrets of Successful Fishing
results.brief_description: John Turnbull explains the finer points to be considered when selecting and balancing tackle. He covers spinning tackle, plug casting and fly fishing tackle and shows how to cast with it, using sidecast, backcast, roll cast and fast retrieve techniques.
results.description: John Turnbull explains the finer points to be considered when selecting and balancing tackle. He covers spinning tackle, plug casting and fly fishing tackle and shows how to cast with it, using sidecast, backcast, roll cast and fast retrieve techniques.

results.title: Weather does its thing
results.creator_credit: Selig Alkon, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and United Nations
results.brief_description: The film looks at the human relationship to climate and shows how in the past we have changed our weather for the worse. The World Weather Watch is followed and the interchange of facts taking place between the World Weather Watch Centres at Washington, Moscow and Melbourne is seen. The significance of WWW is explained by David A. Davies, Secretary-General of the World Meteorological Organisation.

results.title: Heroes Unsung
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Last dream: a special report by John Pilger”.
Part One of a three part series which explores aspects of Australia’s history. In this part, John Pilger traces the history of Australian immigration, from a personal perspective, from the horrors of the First Fleet through to the “White Australia” policy and the post-war “Populate or Perish” program. He challenges Australia’s treasured stereotypes and self-image and instead shows the great hardships suffered by certain groups, namely convicts, immigrants, women and Aborigines, in the process of building the nation.

results.title: Other people's wars
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Last dream: a special report by John Pilger”.
The final episode of a three part series which explores aspects of Australia’s history. This part shows how Australians fight mostly against people with whom they have no quarrel and who offer them no threat of invasion. From the Boxer Rebellion in China to the Boer War in Africa, to the disaster in Vietnam, Australians have paid a unique blood sacrifice to appease a great protector.

results.title: Wealth of a nation
results.creator_credit: William Greaves and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description: Illustrates that individual expressions of freedom of action and thought in all areas of life - social, economic and political - are evidence of the strength and progress of a nation. Citizens of all walks of life are shown in pursuit of their own area of thought and action.
